meanings.definition: To behave in a haughty or disdainful manner.
meanings.sent1: She was cavaliering towards her classmates, acting superior and dismissive.
meanings.sent2: He was always cavaliering towards the staff, never showing respect for their hard work.
meanings.sent3: The cat was cavaliering around the house, ignoring everyone as if it ruled the place.
meanings.sent4: His cavaliering attitude towards the rules made him a rebel in the eyes of his peers.
meanings.sent5: The politician's cavaliering behavior towards the public cost him their trust.

meanings.definition: A supporter of King Charles I during the English Civil War.
meanings.sent1: The cavaliering soldier fought bravely for King Charles I in the Civil War.
meanings.sent2: Many nobles were known for their cavaliering loyalty to the king during the war.
meanings.sent3: The children playfully pretended to be cavaliering knights from the past.
meanings.sent4: In the historical reenactment, he portrayed a cavaliering supporter of the king with pride.
meanings.sent5: The painting depicted a group of cavaliering men standing by King Charles I.

meanings.sent1: He was known as a true cavaliering gentleman, always courteous and brave.
meanings.sent2: The knight's actions on the battlefield were truly cavaliering, inspiring others.
meanings.sent3: The dog's playful antics made him seem like a cavaliering hero in the eyes of the children.
meanings.sent4: His cavaliering demeanor won the hearts of many, earning him the title of a gallant man.
meanings.sent5: In the story, the prince was described as a cavaliering figure, ready to defend his kingdom.
